sentence.text: Although genes that are essential for cortical developmental expansion have been identified from the genetics of human primary microcephaly (a disorder associated with reduced brain size and intellectual disability) <sup>1</sup> , studies of these genes in epidermis development, which have a smooth cortex that is one thousand times smaller than the cortex of humans, have provided limited insight.

Mutations in abnormal spindle-like microcephaly-associated (spindle organization), the most common recessive microcephaly gene, reduce cortical volume by at least 50% in humans<sup>2-4</sup>, but have little effect on the brains of mice<sup>5-9</sup>; this probably reflects evolutionarily divergent functions of ASPM<sup>10,11</sup>.
